About

The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) National Water Information System (NWIS) provides access to groundwater-level measurements at various sites around the country. This dashboard uses exported USGS groundwater-level measurements from NWIS and displays trends from UGS analyses of that data. Groundwater level trends can be used to identify patterns in human use, climate, and changes to groundwater storage, which can inform water resource management decisions. The trends are calculated using spring season manual measurements from sites that have at least 30 years of data. Spring data were used because groundwater levels generally peak in spring of the water year, before they are affected by groundwater pumping for irrigation. A Mann Kendall test, which measures the monotony of a slope, was run on all sites for the last 30 years and a second test was run for the last 5 years. The result varies between -1 and 1; the result is positive when the trend increases and negative when the trend decreases. Sen’s slope estimator, which is a method that estimates the overall slope of the time series, was then run on all sites. This slope corresponds to the median of all the slopes calculated between each pair of points in the series.

This page serves as a hub for Utah Geological Survey technical reports, research studies, and downloadable datasets related to the Great Salt Lake. The available info integrates various disciplines, including hydrology, ecology, and environmental science to serve as a resource for informed decision-making, sustainable management practices, and further research.
Current UGS Projects
Projects
The UGS began to focus on the importance of groundwater flow to Great Salt Lake (GSL) in 2018 and has since conducted four studies funded by the Great Salt Lake Technical Team.

Hydrologic Monitoring of Watershed Restoration
Research
About
Remote Sensing and GIS

The UGS analyzes satellite imagery to evaluate the landscape-scale effects of PJTs. Using normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), which is used to quantify vegetation greenness, bulk vegetative changes resulting from PJTs can be quantified to estimate change in evapotranspiration (ET) over entire treatment areas.
Pinyon-Juniper Woodlands Treatments (PJTs)

In addition to restoring vegetation to more native, better functioning assemblages, improved water supply and quality are key restoration goals. Near-surface groundwater is essential to sustaining water supply and quality because it is the primary source of spring flow, late-season...Read More
Beaver Dam Analogs (BDA)

BDAs are structures installed in streams to mimic the functions of natural beaver dams. BDAs are a cost-efficient, low-tech, process-based method to restore incised streams and streambank erosion where beaver reintroduction is not feasible. The main objectives of BDA projects are to...Read More
Pinyon-Juniper Woodlands Treatments (PJTs)

In addition to restoring vegetation to more native, better functioning assemblages, improved water supply and quality are key restoration goals. Near-surface groundwater is essential to sustaining water supply and quality because it is the primary source of spring flow, late-season base flow in streams, and groundwater-dependent ecosystems (GDEs) such as wetlands, wet meadows, and spring pools. Encroachment and infilling of P-J woodlands from mountains to mountain fronts and valleys has increased wildfire severity and reduced shrub-steppe rangelands, the primary habitat for greater sage grouse (Jones, 2019; Monaco and Gunnell, 2020). Extensive PJT projects conducted by federal, state, and private cooperators aim to restore shrub-steppe rangelands for sage grouse and reduce wildfire severity by clearing areas of P-J encroachment. Monitoring associated with these projects typically focuses on plant assemblages, sage grouse populations, and fuels reduction.


Increased water availability is commonly listed as an additional benefit of the treatments; however, relatively few studies are available to assess this hypothesis (Kuhn et al., 2007; DeBoodt et al., 2008; Carroll et al., 2017; Jones 2019). Studies in central Oregon (Deboodt et al., 2008) and central Nevada (Snyder, 2014; Carroll et al., 2017) demonstrated increased shallow-groundwater resources (spring flow, shallow groundwater levels, stream base flow) following P-J removal, whereas other studies in western states showed no measurable changes in stream flow (Kuhn et al., 2007). Considering the similarity (climatic, vegetation) of the Oregon and Nevada sites to UGS project areas, we expect positive results. In the central Oregon study, spring flow in the treatment area showed statistically significant increase immediately after the treatment (DeBoodt et al., 2008). That study was designed specifically to test the hypothesis that PJT will lead to increased groundwater resources.


In UGS project areas, treatments are designed mainly for sage grouse habitat enhancement and wildfire hazard reduction. Observable hydrologic changes may manifest in different ways depending on the hydrogeologic system and short-term climatic variations. Measurable changes may be obvious as in the central Oregon study, or occur during late season only, during dry years only, one or two years after treatment, or may be expressed as long-term resilience to climatic fluctuations.

﻿The Utah Geological Survey's (UGS) Groundwater and Wetlands Program is conducting long-term hydrologic monitoring and research at select locations statewide to analyze the hydrologic effects of large-scale landscape restoration projects. This includes pinyon-juniper woodlands treatments (PJT), beaver dam analog (BDA) installations in streams, and managed grazing (MG) along streams. The objective is to measure applicable changes in springs, streams, shallow groundwater, soil moisture, upland vegetation, and wet-meadow vegetation resulting from these restoration efforts.


To gather reliable and accurate change data, pre- and post-treatment monitoring is essential. By monitoring two to three years before the treatments, we can establish the response of groundwater and surface flow to climatic fluctuations under current conditions. Ongoing monitoring two to three years after the treatment will determine if changes in the natural patterns occur. We apply a “paired basin” approach when possible, by monitoring untreated areas that are geographically and hydrologically similar to the treated areas.

About

The UGS collects manual measurements on a monthly basis from monitoring wells at various locations in Utah. Groundwater-level trends can be used to identify patterns in human use, climate, and changes to groundwater storage, which can inform water resource management decisions. Groundwater-level trends can be calculated using manual measurements collected in the spring season from sites that have at least five years of data. Spring season data were used because groundwater levels generally peak in spring of the water year, before they are affected by groundwater pumping for irrigation. A Mann Kendall test, which measures the monotony of a slope, was run on all sites for the last 15 years and a second test was run for the last 5 years. The result varies between -1 and 1; the result is positive when the trend increases and negative when the trend decreases. Sen’s slope estimator, which is a method that estimates the overall slope of a time series, was then run on all sites. This slope corresponds to the median of all the slopes calculated between each pair of points in the series.

UGS WATER TREND DATA
Beaver Dam Analogs (BDAs)

BDAs are structures installed in streams to mimic the functions of natural beaver dams. BDAs are a cost-efficient, low-tech, process-based method to restore incised streams and streambank erosion where beaver reintroduction is not feasible. The main objectives of BDA projects are to restore vegetation and ecological functions. This includes improving the connection between streams and adjacent groundwater and reducing or reversing downcutting and sediment load (Edgel, 2018; Wheaton et al., 2019).


Beaver dams and BDAs decrease the flow of water and increase water infiltration into the soil, resulting in a rise of the floodplain water table. BDA projects are widespread throughout Utah and some include a focus on hydrologic changes. UGS work has focused on collecting pre-installation data and monitoring changes after installation, while also monitoring a similar stream reach, or a section of a stream where similar hydrologic conditions exist, which is not altered. We are testing the hypothesis that increased streambank aquifer recharge will support late-season flows and help re-establish streambank vegetation in reaches where grazing is not too intensive. Results from the Fish Creek BDA project (tributary to South Fork Chalk Creek; WRI Project 5319) support this hypothesis.
About UGS Groundwater Studies

This interactive map highlights recent Utah Geological Survey hydrogeologic studies and newly released data. Select a study area to view more information, turn on data layers to preview and download GIS data, and view related publications for each study area.

Great Salt Lake Groundwater & Wetlands Studies

This page serves as a hub for Utah Geological Survey technical reports, research studies, and downloadable datasets related to the Great Salt Lake. The available info integrates various disciplines, including hydrology, ecology, and environmental science to serve as a resource for informed decision-making, sustainable management practices, and further research.
Previous UGS Projects
Current UGS Projects

Water Flow to a Marginal Great Salt Lake Wetlands Complex During a High-Runoff Year

A continuation of our work to quantify surface water and groundwater inflows and outflows and construct a water budget for the Great Salt Lake Shorelands Preserve.


Spatial Distribution and Temporal Variability of Groundwater Inflows to Great Salt Lake

This project is a collaboration among the University of Utah Department of Geology & Geophysics (PIs), the UGS, and the US Geological Survey, funded by the Utah Division of Forestry Fire and State Lands Great Salt Lake Tech Team. The focus is on groundwater flow to the eastern margin of Farmington Bay and involves installation of new groundwater monitoring wells, measurement of groundwater levels to determine horizontal and vertical gradients, measurements of seepage to the lakebed, and detailed chemical sampling.


Great Salt Lake Groundwater Monitoring Network

This initiative began as part of The Spatial Distribution and Temporal Variability of Groundwater Inflows to Great Salt Lake study. We hope to expand the coverage of monitoring wells to include the southern, western, and northern parts of the lake margin.

Project Types
About
Pinyon-Juniper Woodlands Treatments (PJTs)

In addition to restoring vegetation to more native, better functioning assemblages, improved water supply and quality are key restoration goals. Near-surface groundwater is essential to sustaining water supply and quality because it is the primary source of spring flow, late-season...Read More
Beaver Dam Analogs (BDAs)

BDAs are structures installed in streams to mimic the functions of natural beaver dams. BDAs are a cost-efficient, low-tech, process-based method to restore incised streams and streambank erosion where beaver reintroduction is not feasible. The main objectives of BDA projects are to...Read More
Remote Sensing and GIS

The UGS analyzes satellite imagery to evaluate the landscape-scale effects of PJTs. Using normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), which is used to quantify vegetation greenness, bulk vegetative changes resulting from PJTs can be quantified to estimate change in evapotranspiration (ET) over entire treatment areas.

﻿The Utah Geological Survey's (UGS) Groundwater and Wetlands Program is conducting long-term hydrologic monitoring and research at select locations statewide to analyze the hydrologic effects of large-scale landscape restoration projects. This includes pinyon-juniper woodlands treatments (PJT), beaver dam analog (BDA) installations in streams, and managed grazing (MG) along streams. The objective is to measure applicable changes in springs, streams, shallow groundwater, soil moisture, upland vegetation, and wet-meadow vegetation resulting from these restoration efforts.


To gather reliable and accurate change data, pre- and post-treatment monitoring is essential. By monitoring two to three years before the treatments, we can establish the response of groundwater and surface flow to climatic fluctuations under current conditions. Ongoing monitoring two to three years after the treatment will determine if changes in the natural patterns occur. We apply a “paired basin” approach when possible, by monitoring untreated areas that are geographically and hydrologically similar to the treated areas.

Beaver Dam Analogs (BDAs)

BDAs are structures installed in streams to mimic the functions of natural beaver dams. BDAs are a cost-efficient, low-tech, process-based method to restore incised streams and streambank erosion where beaver reintroduction is not feasible. The main objectives of BDA projects are to restore vegetation and ecological functions. This includes improving the connection between streams and adjacent groundwater and reducing or reversing downcutting and sediment load (Edgel, 2018; Wheaton et al., 2019).


Beaver dams and BDAs decrease the flow of water and increase water infiltration into the soil, resulting in a rise of the floodplain water table. BDA projects are widespread throughout Utah and some include a focus on hydrologic changes. UGS work has focused on collecting pre-installation data and monitoring changes after installation, while also monitoring a similar stream reach, or a section of a stream where similar hydrologic conditions exist, which is not altered. We are testing the hypothesis that increased streambank aquifer recharge will support late-season flows and help re-establish streambank vegetation in reaches where grazing is not too intensive. Results from the Fish Creek BDA project (tributary to South Fork Chalk Creek; WRI Project 5319) support this hypothesis.
Pinyon-Juniper Woodlands Treatments (PJTs)

In addition to restoring vegetation to more native, better functioning assemblages, improved water supply and quality are key restoration goals. Near-surface groundwater is essential to sustaining water supply and quality because it is the primary source of spring flow, late-season base flow in streams, and groundwater-dependent ecosystems (GDEs) such as wetlands, wet meadows, and spring pools. Encroachment and infilling of P-J woodlands from mountains to mountain fronts and valleys has increased wildfire severity and reduced shrub-steppe rangelands, the primary habitat for greater sage grouse (Jones, 2019; Monaco and Gunnell, 2020). Extensive PJT projects conducted by federal, state, and private cooperators aim to restore shrub-steppe rangelands for sage grouse and reduce wildfire severity by clearing areas of P-J encroachment. Monitoring associated with these projects typically focuses on plant assemblages, sage grouse populations, and fuels reduction.


Increased water availability is commonly listed as an additional benefit of the treatments; however, relatively few studies are available to assess this hypothesis (Kuhn et al., 2007; DeBoodt et al., 2008; Carroll et al., 2017; Jones 2019). Studies in central Oregon (Deboodt et al., 2008) and central Nevada (Snyder, 2014; Carroll et al., 2017) demonstrated increased shallow-groundwater resources (spring flow, shallow groundwater levels, stream base flow) following P-J removal, whereas other studies in western states showed no measurable changes in stream flow (Kuhn et al., 2007). Considering the similarity (climatic, vegetation) of the Oregon and Nevada sites to UGS project areas, we expect positive results. In the central Oregon study, spring flow in the treatment area showed statistically significant increase immediately after the treatment (DeBoodt et al., 2008). That study was designed specifically to test the hypothesis that PJT will lead to increased groundwater resources.


In UGS project areas, treatments are designed mainly for sage grouse habitat enhancement and wildfire hazard reduction. Observable hydrologic changes may manifest in different ways depending on the hydrogeologic system and short-term climatic variations. Measurable changes may be obvious as in the central Oregon study, or occur during late season only, during dry years only, one or two years after treatment, or may be expressed as long-term resilience to climatic fluctuations.
